sentences.sentence: The election is over and ministerial briefing binders in Ottawa are ready for their new owners.
Unfortunately, most will include only a few sentences about cannabis.
The federal bureaucracy is still mainly patting itself on the back for legalizing recreational cannabis in 2019 and patronizingly reminding the cannabis industry how lucky it was to be born.
Some of this self-satisfaction is warranted but many serious issues need to be addressed.
The cannabis regulatory framework was rushed into existence.
The regulatory text was not even consulted on.
And implementation has been haphazard at best.

If these shortcomings are not fixed, Canada's young cannabis industry may never grow to its full potential.Although the Cannabis Act is up for review later this year, Health Canada has already told industry stakeholders that only "limited resources" are available for the review.

Add to this the fact that the cannabis industry is currently fractured and not nearly as strong or bold as the food or pharmaceutical lobbies and there is a real chance the opportunity to fix key cannabis issues will be missed.Cannabis is now a sizable part of the Canadian economy.
According to Statistics Canada, it accounts for $18.3 billion of GDP.
That's over a third the contribution of agriculture, forestry and fisheries combined.

Current recreational sales exceed $3.5 billion a year though producer margins remain low and governments often make more on sales than the companies doing the manufacturing.The industry's rapid growth has taken place despite badly designed excise taxes and GST.
Health Canada also takes 2.3 per cent of sales for a new "annual regulatory fee" (yet still somehow lacks resources for a decent review of the act).
Provincial governments and their agencies also impose massive mark-up fees - estimated at around 50 per cent for the Ontario Cannabis Store, though the actual number is a secret.

The result of governments taking such a large slice is a high price that makes it hard for the industry to compete with the cannabis black market, which was the main goal of legalization.Opinion: Want a COVID booster?
Maybe you should pay for it(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-want-a-covid-booster-maybe-you-should-pay-for-it)Allan Lanthier: How do we pay for the Liberals' campaign promises?

We don't(https://financialpost.com/opinion/allan-lanthier-how-do-we-pay-for-the-liberals-campaign-promises-we-dont)Opinion: Oil and gas taxes pay for a lot of social benefits(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-oil-and-gas-taxes-pay-for-a-lot-of-social-benefits)The rushed writing of the cannabis regulations led to marketing restrictions that are stricter than for alcohol or tobacco, even though cannabis is generally regarded as being safer than both.
Overly strict regulations may actually increase health risk since, for example, it is illegal to sell cannabis using the same safe propellant formulation used in medical inhalers.
Allowing more THC (the chemical that makes you high) in edibles would help nudge people away from smoking or inhaling and towards ingesting, which is less risky.

In the 15 U.S. states that have legalized recreational cannabis, THC limits for edibles are normally 10 times what is permitted in Canada.Another key issue is wasted opportunity in cannabinol (CBD), a non-intoxicating chemical found in cannabis plants, including legal hemp, that is popular in wellness products around the world.
At the moment, we regulate CBD almost as strictly as we do THC.
For example, only cannabis-licensed producers can make CBD products of any type; CBD can only be sold in cannabis stores; and CBD exports and imports are only allowed for medical use.
In the U.S., by contrast, CBD is much less regulated: farmers, producers and retailers can handle pure CBD freely.
Health Canada held consultations on this issue in 2019.

But progress has since stalled: a science committee the department formed has met only twice, and not at all this year, according to a government website.Other issues that need to be tackled are: barriers to Indigenous involvement in the cannabis industry; a one-size-fits-all excise duty that negatively impacts small craft growers; production red tape (e.g., not being able sell six packs of cannabis drinks and needing a federally security-cleared person on-site for cannabis production); and a general lack of accountability and service standards at Health Canada.Not addressing these problems, which may be a temptation for a new government with a full plate, will result in an industry that can't keep up with the black market and a regulatory framework that becomes an example of how not to effectively regulate cannabis.
Canada took a brave first step in legalizing cannabis.
It now needs to follow through to ensure success.Financial PostShane Morris runs a global cannabis consultancy.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2021 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
